supporting.text: Adidas is a global sportswear brand that produces a wide range of products, including shoes, clothing, and accessories, which are all designed by their in-house teams.

attacks.text: Adidas is a global sportswear brand that produces a wide range of products, including shoes, clothing, and accessories, which are all designed by their in-house teams.
Many Adidas products are actually designed by third-party manufacturers or collaborators, not exclusively by in-house teams.
Adidas outsources a significant portion of its design work to external agencies and freelancers, reducing the role of in-house teams.
Some Adidas products are rebranded or slightly modified versions of existing designs from other brands or suppliers.
Even if third parties are involved, Adidas retains final approval and creative control over all designs, ensuring they reflect the brand's vision.
Collaborations and outsourcing are common industry practices that do not negate Adidas's role as the primary designer of its products.
Rebranding or modifying existing designs still requires significant design input and adaptation to meet Adidas's standards and aesthetics.
Final approval does not equate to original design work; Adidas may still rely heavily on external creativity rather than in-house innovation.
Industry practices do not change the fact that Adidas's reliance on external designers diminishes the claim of in-house design dominance.

supporting.text: Adidas collaborates with designers and celebrities to create unique collections, demonstrating their active role in the design process.

attacks.text: Adidas collaborates with designers and celebrities to create unique collections, demonstrating their active role in the design process.
Collaboration does not necessarily mean Adidas itself is doing the design work; the actual design could be outsourced to external parties.
Celebrity collaborations often focus on branding rather than actual design input, which may not reflect Adidas' internal design capabilities.
Even if external designers are involved, Adidas still oversees and approves the designs, indicating their active participation in the process.
Many collaborations involve co-creation where Adidas designers work alongside external partners, proving their direct involvement in design.
Branding-focused collaborations still require design input from Adidas to align with their product standards and aesthetic.
Approval does not equate to active design participation; it could merely be a managerial or marketing decision.
Co-creation does not guarantee equal contribution; external designers might lead the process with minimal Adidas input.

supporting.text: Adidas holds numerous design patents and trademarks, indicating their involvement in creating original designs.

attacks.text: Adidas holds numerous design patents and trademarks, indicating their involvement in creating original designs.
Holding design patents does not necessarily mean Adidas designs all items themselves; they may outsource design work to third parties.
Trademarks protect brand identity, not necessarily the design process, so they do not prove Adidas designs items.
Adidas has in-house design teams and publicly showcases their designers, which demonstrates direct involvement in the design process.
Even if some designs are outsourced, Adidas still oversees and approves all designs, maintaining creative control.
Trademarks often cover distinctive design elements, which implies Adidas contributes to the design of these elements.
Public showcases of designers could be for marketing purposes and may not reflect the actual extent of their involvement in all designs.
Approval of outsourced designs does not equate to original creation, as the core design work is done by others.

supporting.text: Adidas primarily outsources manufacturing to third-party factories, which might imply they focus less on design and more on branding and distribution.

attacks.text: Adidas primarily outsources manufacturing to third-party factories, which might imply they focus less on design and more on branding and distribution.
Outsourcing manufacturing does not necessarily mean Adidas focuses less on design; many companies outsource production while maintaining strong design teams.
Adidas invests heavily in design innovation, as evidenced by their collaborations with designers and athletes, which contradicts the claim that they focus less on design.
Even if Adidas maintains design teams, outsourcing can dilute control over the final product quality, indirectly affecting design integrity.
Collaborations do not always reflect core design capabilities; they might be marketing strategies rather than evidence of strong in-house design.
Adidas has strict quality control measures with third-party manufacturers, ensuring design integrity is maintained despite outsourcing.

supporting.text: Some Adidas products are co-branded or licensed from other companies, meaning the design work may not always be done by Adidas themselves.

attacks.text: Some Adidas products are co-branded or licensed from other companies, meaning the design work may not always be done by Adidas themselves.
Even if some designs are co-branded, Adidas still oversees and approves all final designs, ensuring their brand standards are met.
Co-branding is a common industry practice and does not negate Adidas's role as the primary designer in most of their products.
Overseeing designs is not the same as creating them; approval does not equate to original design work.
The majority of Adidas's revenue comes from products they design in-house, making co-branding exceptions statistically insignificant.
Approval processes often involve significant input and modifications, which can be considered a form of design contribution.
